sentences.sentence: The following editorial ran in a recent edition of the Telegraph-Journal.In our country, hockey is the closest thing to a religion outside of church itself.That's why the stunning revelations of the past two months have shaken our faith - not in the game, but in the people entrusted to lead the sport and promote our values as Canadians.In May we learned Hockey Canada settled a $3.55-million lawsuit, which alleged a group of major junior players, including members of the national junior team, sexually assaulted a woman in a hotel room.

The undisclosed settlement amount is on top of $7.6 million paid to nine sexual assault victims over the last three decades.For shame, Hockey Canada's leadership did not act with the care or urgency befitting such a heinous incident.
Under fire from a parliamentary committee this week, those leaders have been profuse in their regret for what happened - but these apologies ring hollow.

In particular, their claim they've paid out financial settlements to help victims, not evade responsibility, is plainly unconvincing.The upshot is obvious: Hockey Canada has lost the country's trust.There is clearly a major problem of culture in high-performance programs for young players.

While these programs are doing a great job producing star athletes, they are not instilling one of our most important national values: respect for women.After all, this alleged incident was not about one rogue player.
According to the victim, eight players were in that room.
None of them had the character or decency to stop the assault.Culture is the problem, but cultures take time, effort and discipline to change.
Our elite hockey environment's toxic attitude toward women will not turn around overnight.But that doesn't mean we wait.
Indeed, before reform must come accountability.There is no place at the table for any of the current board members or executives with Hockey Canada moving forward.
They have had their chance to fix these problems and they have failed.
Even if they were not personally involved in the response to this incident, they have not demonstrated the qualities to guide the organization.It is time to put the padlock on Hockey Canada.
Tear it down to the studs and start over again.This begins with appointing a new leadership structure whose primary mandate is to address these fundamental problems.

The institution's top officials must be champions for hockey - but also the reality that some things are more important than hockey.If that means having to put major programs or events on hold, then so be it.No matter how many NHL players Hockey Canada produces, it will not make up for what happened here.
Our national sport's governing body must regain the trust that it has everyone's best interests at heart - not just the athletes'.
The only way to do this is to start anew.Sabrina Maddeaux: What else is Hockey Canada hiding from us?

(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/sabrina-maddeaux-what-else-is-hockey-canada-hiding-from-us)Scott Stinson: The glaring question that Hockey Canada's executives have yet to answer(https://nationalpost.com/sports/scott-stinson-the-glaring-question-that-hockey-canadas-executives-have-yet-to-answer) !

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
